ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Broader understanding of the ideas of borders and identity. Taking on perspective from new lenses (.e.g. Focault). Better technical understanding of real world border conflicts and migration.
Thinking about what borders are, how they are constructed, how they influence and are influenced by various social forces, how they interact with concepts of state, sovereignty, freedom, and so on.
Understanding of what borders mean, who they implicate, what they are. A really good mix of an anthropological / philosophical understanding of the border, migrants, borderlands, nationhood rtc
I learned a lot about the theory and realities of borders around the world. It was a cool combination of theory and case studies.
great class that really challenged my existing thoughts and perceptions on borders, their purpose, and where they're located

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: More technical information at the start of the class before applying perspectives. Providing primary source readings from both sides of border conflicts and reconciling those perspectives in class.

Strength: interesting people, Leslie and Shivangi are cool and very smart. Focus on process rather than product, a nice community of learning. Weakness: assignments (4 papers) are somewhat trivial and very open-ended.
Strengths: Really interesting readings, knowledgeable professor, good discussions

sometimes the reading was pretty dense and I felt like I didn't have enough time to fully digest the material before class discussion; the majority of the readings and discussions, though, were extremely thought provoking and left me constantly thinking about the class

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes for those who would like to take ER&M and theoretical perspective to a commonly technical topic.

Yes, it was interesting! You have to come in with an open mind because some of the readings have kind of strange takes but Leslie does a good job of curating the class so that we hear a wide variety of different perspectives, and we can decide for ourselves what is convincing.
Absolutely this is a really really amazing course please take !!

I would recommend this class to a student who is willing and able to invest time in it! I enjoyed the course and definitely got exposure to the world of border studies and the language used within it, which is helpful as an activist, but I would've gotten a lot more out of the course I think if I'd been able to spend more time with the material.

I would highly recommend it. It is super fascinating to learn about how borders impact our daily lives, as well as different case studies that show the similarities and differences that borders produce.
great course to challenge perceptions on borders and their pervasiveness-- extremely enlightening
